titlestmt.titleproper: Wagner Free Institute of Science printer's plates 1883-1883
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012

did.unittitle: Wagner Free Institute of Science printer's plates

bioghist.p: Incorporated by William Wagner in 1855, the Wagner Free Institute is a natural history museum and educational institution in Philadelphia that is dedicated to providing free public education in the sciences. William Wagner originally offered free lectures and classes in his home and at Spring Garden Hall. He later constructed an Institute building, which opened to the public in 1865.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a set of 12 printing plates, on copper mounted onto wooden blocks. These plates were used to print various documents, including the 1883 announcements of the Wagner Free Institute of Science, rosters of the trustees and faculty, the Institute's Act of Incorporation, and a record of the transfer of deed from William and Louisa Wagner to the Institute. Three plates are dated 1883; the others are undated.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: An inventory is available in the repository.
